title: 2024 - Alberta | Oil company fined for exposing animals to toxins
keypoints: Canadian Natural Resources (CNRL) fined $278,000 by Alberta Energy Regulator for wildlife exposure to toxins in tailings ponds.
Incident led to death of 411 birds, with coyotes and wolves also affected.
The company failed to prevent the formation of an island in the tailings pond, attracting wildlife.
Mitigation measures were ineffective, but a fence was eventually installed to prevent further wildlife harm.
The tailings ponds lie on a major bird migration route, posing ongoing risks despite preventative measures.

title: Dangote Refinery: Crude oil supply options
keypoints: International oil companies (IOCs) in Nigeria have refused to sell crude oil to Dangote Refinery at market prices.
Dangote has secured funding from international banks, proving the refinery's viability.
Nigeria's federal government has been unable to compel IOCs to establish local refineries.
NNPCL is seen as complicit with IOCs, prioritizing its interests over national refinery support.
Dangote Refinery imports crude from the USA, impacting its cost competitiveness.
NNPCL owes Dangote Refinery $1.7 billion in crude oil supply as part of its equity stake.

title: OPEC: Global crude oil demand will rise to 116m bpd in 2045
keypoints: OPEC forecasts global oil demand to reach 116 million barrels per day by 2045.
The world economy is expected to double in size, reaching $270 trillion by 2045.
Urbanization and population growth (over 9.5 billion people by 2045) will drive demand.
Significant investment ($14 trillion) needed in oil-related sectors to meet future demand.
OPEC emphasizes the importance of securing investment to maintain supply security and avoid volatility.
OPEC continues to advocate for fair climate finance and technology adaptation.

title: Oil futures: Crude prices extend losses on economic, demand concerns
keypoints: Oil futures prices fell due to concerns over global economic growth.
ICE Brent and NYMEX WTI futures saw declines amid prospects of a US rate cut.
China's disappointing GDP figures and reduced oil throughput contributed to market pessimism.
Geopolitical tensions, including Houthi attacks on oil tankers, added to market instability.
The North Sea physical market also saw reduced trading prices for flagship Forties crude.
